author: KARLI VANCLEAVE | WSYX Stsff
title: chevron-right
text: {p}Thursday, January 11,{ } 2024{/p}{p}Good Thursday morning! We start with a fresh layer of snow on the roads! This snow will be quite brief and only for the early morning hours. Light snowfall accumulations are expected and a few slick spots are possible this morning.{ } Any chance of snow will be gone by midday. Thursday afternoon will be cloudy. Highs will be in the lower 30s. The wind will be out of the west at 10 to 15 mph. Thursday night will be mostly cloudy. Lows will be in the mid 20s.{/p}{p}Confidence in a winter storm impacting Michiana Friday through Friday night continues to grow. A WINTER STORM WATCH has been issued for Elkhart, LaGrange, La Porte, and St. Joseph Co., IN and Berrien, Cass, St. Joseph Co., MI. This is where the heaviest snow will fall and the worst travel conditions will develop. Snowfall totals within the watch area will likely be near or above 6\{p}Parents are reacting to the Ohio House of Representative's decision to override the {a href=\"https://thenationaldesk.com/top-videos/ohio-house-senate-gov-mike-dewine-hb-bill-68-trans-bill-safe-act-veto-override-politics-government-transgender#\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"https://thenationaldesk.com/top-videos/ohio-house-senate-gov-mike-dewine-hb-bill-68-trans-bill-safe-act-veto-override-politics-government-transgender#\"}governor's veto of H.B. 68{/a}. The state Senate{ }confirmed Thursday that it plans to follow suit when it convenes later this month.{/p}{p}The bill makes it illegal for minors in Ohio to take puberty blockers, undergo other hormone therapies or receive gender reassignment surgery, as well as blocks transgender student-athletes from participating in girls' and women's sports.{/p}{p}In a 65-28 vote, the Ohio House decided to keep H.B. 68 in its original language, and now it will be sent to the Senate. If the Senate also successfully votes to override the governor's veto, then H.B. 68 will become law in its original language.{/p}{p}Betty Elswick says she's devastated by the override because if the bill becomes law, her son won't be able to get the medical care he needs.{/p}{blockquote}My teen son, Parker, he's 16. He's been receiving gender-affirming care at a children's hospital in Cincinnati for over a year now,\" Elswick said. \"He's going to lose access to his insurance and healthcare. It's going to make him essentially a medical hot potato.\"{/blockquote}{p}Elswick isn't the only parent who was upset by the override. Sam Shim says his teen will also be affected by this bill if it becomes law.{/p}{p}\"Kids like my own are going to be harmed, and we are going to have more suicides because of this bill,\" Shim said.{/p}{p}Shim says he's worried about transgender youth and believes they'll be calling on state senators to uphold the governor's veto for the future of his own child.{/p}{p}\"Some kids are going to be afraid to talk to their parents or even to talk to their school counselors or their therapists,\" Shim said. \"They're going to be afraid to walk into a hospital because they've realized they're not going to get the care they need.\"{/p}{p}The state Senate will vote on January 24.{/p}{p}Thursday, January 11,{ } 2024{/p}{p}Good Thursday morning! We start with a fresh layer of snow on the roads! This snow will be quite brief and only for the early morning hours. Light snowfall accumulations are expected and a few slick spots are possible this morning.{ } Any chance of snow will be gone by midday. Thursday afternoon will be cloudy. Highs will be in the lower 30s. The wind will be out of the west at 10 to 15 mph. Thursday night will be mostly cloudy. Lows will be in the mid 20s.{/p}{p}Confidence in a winter storm impacting Michiana Friday through Friday night continues to grow. A WINTER STORM WATCH has been issued for Elkhart, LaGrange, La Porte, and St. Joseph Co., IN and Berrien, Cass, St. Joseph Co., MI. This is where the heaviest snow will fall and the worst travel conditions will develop. Snowfall totals within the watch area will likely be near or above 6\{p}Parents are reacting to the Ohio House of Representative's decision to override the {a href=\"https://thenationaldesk.com/top-videos/ohio-house-senate-gov-mike-dewine-hb-bill-68-trans-bill-safe-act-veto-override-politics-government-transgender#\" target=\"_blank\" title=\"https://thenationaldesk.com/top-videos/ohio-house-senate-gov-mike-dewine-hb-bill-68-trans-bill-safe-act-veto-override-politics-government-transgender#\"}governor's veto of H.B. 68{/a}. The state Senate{ }confirmed Thursday that it plans to follow suit when it convenes later this month.{/p}{p}The bill makes it illegal for minors in Ohio to take puberty blockers, undergo other hormone therapies or receive gender reassignment surgery, as well as blocks transgender student-athletes from participating in girls' and women's sports.{/p}{p}In a 65-28 vote, the Ohio House decided to keep H.B. 68 in its original language, and now it will be sent to the Senate. If the Senate also successfully votes to override the governor's veto, then H.B. 68 will become law in its original language.{/p}{p}Betty Elswick says she's devastated by the override because if the bill becomes law, her son won't be able to get the medical care he needs.{/p}{blockquote}My teen son, Parker, he's 16. He's been receiving gender-affirming care at a children's hospital in Cincinnati for over a year now,\" Elswick said. \"He's going to lose access to his insurance and healthcare. It's going to make him essentially a medical hot potato.\"{/blockquote}{p}Elswick isn't the only parent who was upset by the override. Sam Shim says his teen will also be affected by this bill if it becomes law.{/p}{p}\"Kids like my own are going to be harmed, and we are going to have more suicides because of this bill,\" Shim said.{/p}{p}Shim says he's worried about transgender youth and believes they'll be calling on state senators to uphold the governor's veto for the future of his own child.{/p}{p}\"Some kids are going to be afraid to talk to their parents or even to talk to their school counselors or their therapists,\" Shim said. \"They're going to be afraid to walk into a hospital because they've realized they're not going to get the care they need.\"{/p}{p}The state Senate will vote on January 24.{/p}
